1: Most countries don't refrigerate their eggs. In the US, they are considered a perishable item and therefore have to be refrigerated, but they have a surprisingly long shelf life.

All those little random interesting, funny, scary facts, or âdid you knowâ facts you have stored in your brain are there for a reason and will surely come in handy some dayâ¦ even if itâs just so you can beat your best dude at Jeopardy or amaze your bored kiddo while on a family excursion. Just in case you donât have enough info cluttering your brain, here are some more fun, interesting, or just plain zany fun tidbits to keep handy.
449: The legend of the Loch Ness Monster goes back nearly 1,500 years.
450: A group of owls is called a parliament.
451: The surface of Mars is covered in rust, making the planet appear red.
452: Goats have rectangular pupils in their eyes.
453: Greyhounds can run up to 45 mph. So donât challenge one to a race!
454: There is only one country on earth without mosquitoes: Iceland. Its low temperatures make it impossible for the pest to breed.
455: The Supreme Court has its own private basketball court called "the highest court in the land." Pretty clever, if you ask us. It also features a full gym.
456: Blue Ivy Carter is the youngest person ever to appear on a Billboard chart.
457: Kentucky has more bourbon than people.
458: Ketchup was once sold as medicine to treat diarrhea and indigestion. The treatment did not, in fact, work.
459: Slugs have not one, not two, not three... but four noses. They don't work like human noses do, exactly. Instead, they sense chemicals, sounds, lights, and more.
460: Baby koalas are fed poo by their parents after they are born which helps them digest Eucalyptus leaves later in life.
461: More people are killed by vending machines than sharks. Also, more than 90% of shark attacks are on males.
462: A dozen bodies were once found in Benjamin Franklin's basement.
463: Go to bed! Chernobyl, the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill, and the Challenger explosion have all been attributed to a lack of sleep.
464: When visiting Key West, youâre actually closer to Havana than you are to Miami.
465: On average, hair grows about 6 inches per year. As we age, some of these hair follicles stop producing hair, which is why hair loss and balding is common in older people.
466: âA Boy Named Sueâ wasnât written by Johnny Cash. Shel Silverstein wrote it.
468: Michael Jordan and the Chicago Bulls once went eight seasons (starting in 1990) without a three-game losing streak.
469: Want to go to Rome? Which one? Thereâs a city named Rome on six out of seven continents. (You really dropped the ball, Antarctica.)
470: You lose up to 30 percent of your taste buds during flight.
471: The word "MacGyvered" is in the Oxford English Dictionary.
472: It is illegal to sell a "bounceless" pickle to somebody in Connecticut.
473: Forget bald eagles. The turkey was once almost named the national bird.
474: Hiking naked is illegal in Switzerland. Though we must say, it doesnât seem like a good idea in general!
475: Abe Lincoln was a champion wrestler. He was also a licensed bartender. Maybe they should call him an âAbe of all trades.â
476: A mermaid "documentary" once fooled so many people that the U.S. government had to issue a statement.
477: Did you know apples come from the same plant family as roses? So do plums, raspberries, and many other delicious fruits. Next time, instead of roses, just send your mother a lovely bouquet of plums!
479: A shrimpâs heart is located in its head.
480: The average golf ball has 336 dimples.
482: Because of the 4 stages of the Water Cycle – Evaporation, Condensation, Precipitation and Collection – water falling as rain today may have previously fallen as rain days, weeks, months or years before.
483: There's a world record—and a happy ending—for the greatest distance thrown in a car accident.
485: In their lifetime, the average person walks the equivalent of five times around the Earth.

487: The Nobel Peace Prize is named for Alfred Nobel, the inventor of dynamite.
488: The shortest war in history lasted for only 38 minutes.
489: Elephants suck on their trunks for comfort.
490: The first Star Wars was expected to be a flop.
491: Dogs have a dominant paw like humans have a dominant left or right hand. Can you tell if your dog is left-pawed or right-pawed?
492: All clownfish are born male. That explains Marlin and Nemo. They have the ability to change their sex later on.

495: Cows kill more Americans each year than sharks do.

497: Bananas are curved because of how they grow — toward the sun. Also, technically speaking, they're actually defined as a type of berry.
498: More than 100 baseballs are used during a typical professional baseball game.

502: Gatorade was named after the University of Florida Gators.
503: Most people break up on Mondays.
504: A little gross, but also kind of funny: Lobsters pee out of their faces. Even more interesting, they do this as a way to attract mates.
505: Dolphins literally sleep with one eye open because only one of their brain hemispheres sleeps at a time. The left eye closes when the right half of the brain sleeps, and vice versa.
506: The heart of a shrimp is located in its head. Weird, yet kind of cool. Also weird: Shrimp have an open circulatory system, so their organs just float in blood.
507: More human twins are being born now than ever before.

509: There's an entire family in Italy that feels almost no pain.
511: There are 31,556,926 seconds in a year.
512: Despite taking about three hours to play out, the average baseball game only has about 18 minutes of active playing time.
513: The only letter of the alphabet that doesnât appear in any American state is q.
515: Pilots and their co-pilots are required to eat different meals before flights so that they donât both end up with food poisoning.
516: Goosebumps developed to make our ancestorsâ hair stand up, making them appear more threatening to predators.
518: You canât hum while plugging your nose.
519: Detroit undercover cops in a drug ring once fought another group of undercover cops.
520: Water makes different pouring sounds depending on its temperature.
521: One man once survived two atomic bombs.
522: Your small intestine is the largest internal organ in your body.
523: The U.S. almost went to war with Canada over a pig.
524: A horse’s canter is a 3-beat gait. On the second beat, opposite front and rear legs hit the ground at the same time.  After the third beat is a “rest”, or suspension, when all three legs are off the ground.
